 'THE GDELT GLOBAL KNOWLEDGE GRAPH (GKG) 
DATA FORMAT CODEBOOK V2.1 
2/19/2015 
http://gdeltproject.org/  
 
INTRODUCTION 
 
This codebook introduces the GDELT Global Knowledge Graph (GKG) Version 2.1, which expands 
GDELT’s ability to quantify global human society beyond cataloging physical occurrences towards 
actually representing all of the latent dimensions, geography, and network structure of the global news.  
It applies an array of highly sophisticated natural language processing algorithms to each document to 
compute a range of codified metadata encoding key latent and contextual dimensions of the document.  
To sum up the GKG in a single sentence, it connects every person, organization, location, count, theme, 
news source, and event across the planet into a single massive network that captures what’s happening 
around the world, what its context is and who’s involved, and how the world is feeling about it, every 
single day. 
 
It has been just short of sixteen months since the original prototype introduction of the GKG 1.0 system 
on November 3, 2013 and in those fourteen months the GKG system has found application in an 
incredible number and diversity of fields.  The uniqueness of the GKG indicators in capturing the latent 
dimensions of society that precede physical unrest and their global scope has enabled truly 
unimaginable new applications.  We’ve learned a lot over the past year in terms of the features and 
capabilities of greatest interest to the GKG community, and with this Version 2.1 release of the GKG, we 
are both integrating those new features and moving the GKG into production status (from its original 
alpha status) in recognition of the widespread production use of the system today. 
 
Due to the vast number of use cases articulated for the GKG, a decision was made at its release to create 
a raw output format that could be processed into the necessary refined formats for a wide array of 
software packages and analysis needs and that would support a diverse assortment of extremely 
complex analytic needs in a single file.  Unlike the primary GDELT event stream, which is designed for 
direct import into major statistical packages like R, the GKG file format requires more sophisticated 
preprocessing and users will likely want to make use of a scripting language like PERL or Python to 
extract and reprocess the data for import into a statistical package.  Thus, users may require more 
advanced text processing and scripting language skills to work with the GKG data and additional nuance 
may be required when thinking about how to incorporate these indicators into statistical models and 
network and geographic constructs, as outlined in this codebook.  Encoding the GKG in XML, JSON, RDF, 
or other file formats significantly increases the on-disk footprint of the format due to its complexity and 
size (thus why the GKG is only available in CSV format), though users requiring access to the GKG in 
these formats can easily write a PERL or Python or similar script to translate the GKG format to any file 
format needed.  The GKG is optimized for fast scanning, storing one record per line and using a tab-
delimited format to separate the fields. This makes it possible to use highly optimized fully parallelized 
streamed parsing to rapidly process the GKG.  Similar to the 1.0 format, the files have a “.csv” ending, 
despite being tab-delimited, to address issues with some software packages that cannot handle “.txt” or 
“.tsv” endings for parsing tasks. 
 
The new GKG format preserves most of the previous fields in their existing format for backwards 
compatibility (and we will continue to generate the daily Version 1.0 files in parallel into the future), but'
 'or mentions an argument over constitutionalism or a forthcoming policy announcement, will now be 
included in the GKG stream.  Similarly, an article that has no recognizable metadata, but does yield 
GCAM emotional/thematic scores will also be included.  When processing GKG 2.1 files, users should 
therefore be careful not to include any assumptions in their code as to whether an entry has extracted 
geographic information and should check the contents of this field for mapping or other geographic 
applications. 
 
 
EXTRACTED FIELDS 
 
The following section documents each of the fields contained in the GKG 2.1 format.  Note: the former 
format had a NUMARTS field – this has been discontinued due to the new format’s support of multiple 
types of source collections beyond just news media and the requisite need to specify a source collection 
to interpret document identifiers in the new format (as discussed above).  Thus, if multiple documents 
have identical computed metadata, in 1.0 format they would have been clustered together with 
NumArts used to indicate the multiple entries, while in the 2.1 format each document has a separate 
entry in the file.  Fields prefaced with “V1” indicate they are identical in format and population to the 
previous GKG format.  Those prefaced with “V1.5” mean they are largely similar, but have some 
changes.  Those prefaced with “V2” are new to the format.  Each row represents one document codified 
by the GKG and each row is tab-delimited for its major fields.  Note: the “V1/V1.5/V2” designations are 
not included in the header row of the actual GKG output files.  Note:  the ordering of the fields in the file 
has substantially changed from Version 2.0 to Version 2.1.  
 
 
GKGRECORDID.  (string)  Each GKG record is assigned a globally unique identifier.  Unlike the 
EVENT system, which uses semi-sequential numbering to assign numeric IDs to each event 
record, the GKG system uses a date-oriented serial number.  Each GKG record ID takes the form 
“YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-X” or “YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-TX” in which the first portion of the ID is the 
full date+time of the 15 minute update batch that this record was created in, followed by a 
dash, followed by sequential numbering for all GKG records created as part of that update 
batch.  Records originating from a document that was translated by GDELT Translingual will have 
a capital “T” appearing immediately after the dash to allow filtering of English/non-English 
material simply by its record identifier.  Thus, the fifth GKG record created as part of the update 
batch generated at 3:30AM on February 3, 2015 would have a GKGRECORDID of 
“20150203033000-5” and if it was based on a French-language document that was translated, it 
would have the ID “20150203033000-T5”.  This ID can be used to uniquely identify this 
particular record across the entire GKG database.  Note that due to the presence of the dash, 
this field should be treated as a string field and NOT as a numeric field. 
 
V2.1DATE.  (integer)  This is the date in YYYYMMDDHHMMSS format on which the news media 
used to construct this GKG file was published.  NOTE that unlike the main GDELT event stream 
files, this date represents the date of publication of the document from which the information 
was extracted – if the article discusses events in the past, the date is NOT time-shifted as it is for 
the GDELT event stream.  This date will be the same for all rows in a file and is redundant from a 
data processing standpoint, but is provided to make it easier to load GKG files directly into an 
SQL database for analysis.  NOTE: for some special collections this value may be 0 indicating that 
the field is either not applicable or not known for those materials.  For example, OCR’d historical 
document collections may not have robust metadata on publication date.  NOTE: the GKG 2.0 
format still encoded this date in YYYYMMDD format, while under GKG 2.1 it is now in 
YYYYMMDDHHMMSS format.'
 'EVENT TABLE 
 
EVENTID AND DATE ATTRIBUTES 
 
The first few fields of an event record capture its globally unique identifier number, the date the event 
took place on, and several alternatively formatted versions of the date designed to make it easier to 
work with the event records in different analytical software programs that may have specific date 
format requirements.  The parenthetical after each variable name gives the datatype of that field. 
 
Note that even though GDELT 2.0 operates at a 15 minute resolution, the date fields in this section still 
record the date at the daily level, since this is the resolution that event analysis has historically been 
performed at.  To examine events at the 15 minute resolution, use the DATEADDED field (the second 
from the last field in this table at the end).  
 
 
GlobalEventID.  (integer) Globally unique identifier assigned to each event record that uniquely 
identifies it in the master dataset.  NOTE: While these will often be sequential with date, this is 
NOT always the case and this field should NOT be used to sort events by date: the date fields 
should be used for this.  NOTE: There is a large gap in the sequence between February 18, 2015 
and February 19, 2015 with the switchover to GDELT 2.0 – these are not missing events, the ID 
sequence was simply reset at a higher number so that it is possible to easily distinguish events 
created after the switchover to GDELT 2.0 from those created using the older GDELT 1.0 system. 
 
Day.  (integer) Date the event took place in YYYYMMDD format.  See DATEADDED field for 
YYYYMMDDHHMMSS date. 
 
MonthYear.  (integer) Alternative formatting of the event date, in YYYYMM format. 
 
Year.  (integer) Alternative formatting of the event date, in YYYY format. 
 
FractionDate.  (floating point) Alternative formatting of the event date, computed as YYYY.FFFF, 
where FFFF is the percentage of the year completed by that day.  This collapses the month and 
day into a fractional range from 0 to 0.9999, capturing the 365 days of the year.  The fractional 
component (FFFF) is computed as (MONTH * 30 + DAY) / 365.  This is an approximation and does 
not correctly take into account the differing numbers of days in each month or leap years, but 
offers a simple single-number sorting mechanism for applications that wish to estimate the 
rough temporal distance between dates. 
 
 
ACTOR ATTRIBUTES 
 
The next fields describe attributes and characteristics of the two actors involved in the event.  This 
includes the complete raw CAMEO code for each actor, its proper name, and associated attributes.  The 
raw CAMEO code for each actor contains an array of coded attributes indicating geographic, ethnic, and 
religious affiliation and the actor’s role in the environment (political elite, military officer, rebel, etc).  
These 3-character codes may be combined in any order and are concatenated together to form the final 
raw actor CAMEO code.  To make it easier to utilize this information in analysis, this section breaks these 
codes out into a set of individual fields that can be separately queried.  NOTE: all attributes in this 
section other than CountryCode are derived from the TABARI ACTORS dictionary and are NOT 
supplemented from information in the text.  Thus, if the text refers to a group as “Radicalized'
 'shortform of the state’s name (such as “TX” for Texas).  Note: see the notice above for 
CountryCode regarding the FIPS10-4 / GENC transition.  Note: to obtain ADM2 (district-
level) assignments for locations, you can either perform a spatial join against a ShapeFile 
template in any GIS software, or cross-walk the FeatureID to the GNIS/GNS databases – 
this will provide additional fields such as ADM2 codes and MGRS grid references for 
GNS. 
o Location Latitude.  (floating point number) This is the centroid latitude of the landmark 
for mapping.  In the case of a country or administrative division this will reflect the 
centroid of that entire country/division. 
o Location Longitude.  (floating point number) This is the centroid longitude of the 
landmark for mapping.  In the case of a country or administrative division this will reflect 
the centroid of that entire country/division. 
o Location FeatureID.  (text OR signed integer) This is the numeric GNS or GNIS FeatureID 
for this location OR a textual country or ADM1 code.  More information on these values 
can be found in Leetaru (2012).4  Note: This field will be blank or contain a textual ADM1 
code for country or ADM1-level matches – see above.  Note: For numeric GNS or GNIS 
FeatureIDs, this field can contain both positive and negative numbers, see Leetaru 
(2012) for more information on this. 
 
V2ENHANCEDLOCATIONS.  (semicolon-delimited blocks, with pound symbol (“#”) delimited 
fields)  This field is identical to the V1LOCATIONS field with the primary exception of an extra 
field appended to the end of each location block after its FeatureID that lists the approximate 
character offset of the reference to that location in the text.  In addition, if a location appears 
multiple times in the article, it will be listed multiple times in this field.  The only other 
modification from V1LOCATIONS is the addition of a single new field “Location ADM2Code” in 
between “Location ADM1Code” and “Location Latitude”. 5  NOTE: there was an error in this field 
from 2/19/2015 through midday 3/1/2015 that caused the CountryCode field to list the wrong 
country code in some cases. 
 
V1PERSONS.  (semicolon-delimited)  This is the list of all person names found in the text, 
extracted through the Leetaru (2012) algorithm. 6  This name recognition algorithm is unique in 
that it is specially designed to recognize the African, Asian, and Middle Eastern names that yield 
significantly reduced accuracy with most name recognition engines.  This field is identical in 
format and population as the corresponding field in the GKG 1.0  format. 
 
V2ENHANCEDPERSONS.  (semicolon-delimited blocks, with comma-delimited fields)  This 
contains a list of all person names referenced in the document, along with the character offsets 
of approximately where in the document they were found.  Each person reference is separated 
by a semicolon, and within each reference, the person name is specified first, followed by a 
comma, and then the approximate character offset of the reference of that person in the 
document, allowing it to be associated with other entries from other “V2ENHANCED” fields that 
appear in closest proximity to it.  If a person is mentioned multiple times in a document, each 
mention will appear separately in this field. 
 
V1ORGANIZATIONS.  (semicolon-delimited)  This is the list of all company and organization 
names found in the text, extracted through the Leetaru (2012) algorithm. 7  This is a 
combination of corporations, IGOs, NGOs, and any other local organizations such as a local fair 
                                                          
4 http://www.dlib.org/dlib/september12/leetaru/09leetaru.html 
5 http://blog.gdeltproject.org/global-second-order-administrative-divisions-now-available-from-gaul/ 
6 http://www.dlib.org/dlib/september12/leetaru/09leetaru.html 
7 http://www.dlib.org/dlib/september12/leetaru/09leetaru.html']

The main differences between GKG 1.0 and the newer versions (such as GKG 2.1) in terms of data format and usage are as follows:

1. **Data Format and Structure:**
   - **File Format:** Both GKG 1.0 and newer versions use a tab-delimited format with a ".csv" file extension (despite being tab-delimited) to facilitate fast scanning and parallelized parsing. However, the newer versions have substantially changed the ordering of fields compared to GKG 1.0.
   - **Field Naming and Versioning:** Newer versions use prefixes like V1, V1.5, and V2 to indicate whether fields are identical to, slightly changed from, or new compared to the original GKG 1.0 format. This helps maintain backward compatibility while introducing new features.
   - **Unique Record Identifiers:** GKG 2.1 introduces a globally unique GKGRECORDID string that encodes the date and time of the update batch and a sequential number, including a marker for translated documents. This is different from GKG 1.0, which did not have such a detailed unique identifier system.

2. **Content and Metadata Enhancements:**
   - **Date Format:** GKG 1.0 used a simpler date format (YYYYMMDD), while GKG 2.1 uses a more precise date-time format (YYYYMMDDHHMMSS) for the publication date of the source document.
   - **Expanded Source Document Identification:** The newer versions include a more detailed MentionIdentifier field that can contain URLs, textual citations, or DOIs, depending on the MentionType, allowing for more precise and varied document referencing.
   - **Enhanced Location Data:** The newer versions add fields like V2ENHANCEDLOCATIONS, which include additional geographic metadata such as ADM2 codes and character offsets of location mentions in the text, improving geographic precision and enabling better spatial analysis.
   - **Enhanced Person and Organization Data:** GKG 2.1 introduces V2ENHANCEDPERSONS, which not only lists person names but also includes character offsets for each mention, allowing for more granular text analysis and association with other metadata fields. This is an enhancement over the simpler semicolon-delimited lists in GKG 1.0.
   - **Removal of NUMARTS Field:** The NUMARTS field present in GKG 1.0, which indicated the number of articles clustered together, was discontinued in newer versions due to the support for multiple source collections and the need to specify source collections explicitly.

3. **Usage and Processing:**
   - **Complexity and Preprocessing:** The newer GKG formats are designed to support a wider array of complex analytic needs and multiple source types beyond just news media. This requires more sophisticated preprocessing and scripting (e.g., using Python or PERL) to extract and transform the data for statistical or network analysis.
   - **Backward Compatibility:** Most fields from GKG 1.0 are preserved in the newer versions to maintain backward compatibility, but users must be aware of changes in field order and new fields when processing the data.
   - **Increased Scope and Detail:** The newer versions expand the scope of the GKG to include latent dimensions of society, emotional and thematic scores, and more detailed metadata, enabling richer and more nuanced analyses than were possible with GKG 1.0.

In summary, the newer GKG versions improve upon GKG 1.0 by providing more detailed, precise, and varied metadata fields, enhanced geographic and entity information, a more robust unique identifier system, and a more complex but flexible data format designed for advanced analytical use cases.

['adds a series of new capabilities that greatly enhance what can be done with the GKG data, opening 
entirely new analytic opportunities.  Some of the most significant changes: 
 
 
Realtime Measurement of 2,300 Emotions and Themes.  The GDELT Global Content Analysis 
Measures (GCAM) module represents what we believe is the largest deployment of sentiment 
analysis in the world: bringing together 24 emotional measurement packages that together 
assess more than 2,300 emotions and themes from every article in realtime, multilingual 
dimensions natively assessing the emotions of 15 languages (Arabic, Basque, Catalan, Chinese, 
French, Galician, German, Hindi, Indonesian, Korean, Pashto, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, and 
Urdu).  GCAM is designed to enable unparalleled assessment of the emotional undercurrents 
and reaction at a planetary scale by bringing together an incredible array of dimensions, from 
LIWC’s “Anxiety” to Lexicoder’s “Positivity” to WordNet Affect’s “Smugness” to RID’s “Passivity”. 
 
Realtime Translation of 65 Languages.  GDELT 2.0 brings with it the public debut of GDELT 
Translingual, representing what we believe is the largest realtime streaming news machine 
translation deployment in the world: all global news that GDELT monitors in 65 languages, 
representing 98.4% of its daily non-English monitoring volume, is translated in realtime into 
English for processing through the entire GDELT Event and GKG/GCAM pipelines.  GDELT 
Translingual is designed to allow GDELT to monitor the entire planet at full volume, creating the 
very first glimpses of a world without language barriers.  The GKG system now processes every 
news report monitored by GDELT across these 65 languages, making it possible to trace people, 
organizations, locations, themes, and emotions across languages and media systems. 
 
Relevant Imagery, Videos, and Social Embeds.  A large fraction of the world’s news outlets now 
specify a hand-selected image for each article to appear when it is shared via social media that 
represents the core focus of the article.  GDELT identifies this imagery in a wide array of formats 
including Open Graph, Twitter Cards, Google+, IMAGE_SRC, and SailThru formats.  In addition, 
GDELT also uses a set of highly specialized algorithms to analyze the article content itself to 
identify inline imagery of high likely relevance to the story, along with videos and embedded 
social media posts (such as embedded Tweets or YouTube or Vine videos), a list of which is 
compiled.  This makes it possible to gain a unique ground-level view into emerging situations 
anywhere in the world, even in those areas with very little social media penetration, and to act 
as a kind of curated list of social posts in those areas with strong social use. 
 
Quotes, Names, and Amounts.  The world’s news contains a wealth of information on food 
prices, aid promises, numbers of troops, tanks, and protesters, and nearly any other countable 
item.  GDELT 2.0 now attempts to compile a list of all “amounts” expressed in each article to 
offer numeric context to global events.  In parallel, a new Names engine augments the existing 
Person and Organization names engines by identifying an array of other kinds of proper names, 
such as named events (Orange Revolution / Umbrella Movement), occurrences like the World 
Cup, named dates like Holocaust Remembrance Day, on through named legislation like Iran 
Nuclear Weapon Free Act, Affordable Care Act and Rouge National Urban Park Initiative.  Finally, 
GDELT also identifies attributable quotes from each article, making it possible to see the 
evolving language used by political leadership across the world. 
 
Date Mentions.  We’ve heard from many of you the desire to encode the list of date references 
found in news articles and documents in order to identify repeating mentions of specific dates 
as possible “anniversary violence” indicators.  All day, month, and year dates are now extracted 
from each document. 
 
Proximity Context.  Perhaps the greatest change to the overall format from version 1.0 is the 
introduction of the new Proximity Context capability.  The GKG records an enormously rich array'
 ' 
Single Data File.  Previously there were two separate GKG data files, one containing Counts only 
and one containing the full GKG file.  The original rationale for having two separate files was that 
users interested only in counts could download a much smaller daily file, but in practice nearly 
all applications use the full GKG file in order to make use of its thematic and other data fields to 
contextualize those counts and to tie them into the GDELT Event Database.  Thus, we are 
eliminating the separate counts-only file to simplify the GKG data environment. 
 
Production Status.  The GKG has now moved out of Alpha Experimental Release status and into 
production status.  This means that the file format is now stabilized and will not change. 
 
DIFFERENCES FROM GKG 2.0 
 
The GKG 2.0 file format debuted in September 2014 and several special subcollection datasets were 
released in that format.  With the debut of the GKG 2.1 format in February 2015, the format has 
remained largely the same, but with the addition of several new fields to accommodate a number of 
significant enhancements to the GKG system.  While it was originally intended to release these new 
features in the GKG 2.0 format through the V2EXTRASXML field, the integral nature of several of these 
fields, the desire to more closely align some of them with the format used for the Events dataset, and 
the need to enable structural mapping of several of the fields to a forthcoming new hierarchical 
representation, necessitated an upgrade to the GKG file format to the new GKG 2.1 format to 
accommodate these goals.  Users will find that code designed for the GKG 2.0 format can be adapted to 
the GKG 2.1 format with minimal modification.  Since the GKG 2.0 format was only used for a handful of 
special subcollection datasets and never made an appearance for the daily news content, a GKG 2.0 
compatibility feed will not be made available and only the GKG 1.0 and GKG 2.1 formats will be 
supported for news content.   
 
From a conceptual standpoint, two critical differences between the GKG 2.1/2.0 format and the GKG 1.0 
revolve around how entries are clustered and the minimum criteria for an article to be included in the 
GKG stream.  Under the GKG 1.0 format, a deduplication process similar to that used for the Event 
stream was applied to the daily GKG export, grouping together all articles yielding the same GKG

In version 1.0 of the GKG (Global Knowledge Graph) data format, one of the most significant changes introduced was the addition of the **Proximity Context** capability. This new feature fundamentally enhanced the richness and granularity of the data recorded in the GKG.

### Proximity Context Capability

- **What it is:** Proximity Context refers to the detailed recording of the relative positions of key elements within a news article or document. Specifically, it captures the locations (in terms of character offsets or sentence numbers) where actors, actions, and other event components are mentioned within the text.
  
- **Impact on Data Encoding:** This capability allows the GKG to encode not just the presence of date mentions, actors, and events, but also their precise contextual placement within the article. For example, it records the exact character offset where Actor1, Actor2, and the core Action description appear, as well as the sentence number of the event mention.

- **Why it matters:** By knowing the proximity of these elements, analysts can better understand the narrative structure and the relationships between entities in the text. This is crucial for disambiguating ambiguous references (e.g., pronouns like "he" or "his") and for assessing the importance or emphasis of an event within an article based on its position.

### Encoding Date Mentions

- Version 1.0 also introduced the explicit extraction and encoding of **date mentions** found in news articles and documents. This means that all day, month, and year references are now systematically extracted from each document.

- **Use case:** This is particularly useful for identifying "anniversary violence" or recurring events that are referenced repeatedly in the media. By encoding these date mentions, the GKG enables tracking of how specific dates are discussed over time, which can reveal patterns or cycles in news coverage.

### Overall Significance

- The combination of Proximity Context and date mention encoding represents a major step forward in the detail and usability of the GKG data. It allows for more nuanced analysis of news content, including better event disambiguation, temporal pattern recognition, and understanding of narrative emphasis.

- These enhancements support more sophisticated natural language processing and event extraction, improving the accuracy and depth of insights that can be drawn from global news media.

In summary, version 1.0's introduction of Proximity Context and systematic date mention extraction significantly improved the GKG's ability to encode and analyze the structure and timing of events in news articles, enabling richer and more precise global media analytics.

The integration of unique record identifiers into the GDELT Global Knowledge Graph (GKG) improved the system by enabling each GKG record to be uniquely and unambiguously referenced across the entire collection. Specifically:

- **Unique Record Identifiers (GKGRECORDID):** Each GKG record is assigned a globally unique identifier in the form “YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-X” or “YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-TX,” where the first part encodes the date and time of the 15-minute update batch and the suffix is a sequential number for records within that batch. This allows users to uniquely identify and refer to individual GKG records, facilitating better data management, linking, and integration with the GDELT Event Database.

- This addition aligns the GKG with the practices used in the GDELT Event Database, improving consistency and enabling easier cross-referencing between datasets.

Regarding the removal of the counts-only file in the GDELT Event Database context:

- **Elimination of the Counts-Only File:** Previously, there were two separate GKG data files: one containing only counts and a smaller size, and another containing the full GKG data with thematic and other contextual fields. The rationale for having a counts-only file was to provide a smaller file for users interested only in counts.

- However, in practice, nearly all applications use the full GKG file because the thematic and contextual data are essential for understanding and contextualizing the counts and for linking them to the GDELT Event Database.

- Therefore, the counts-only file was removed to simplify the GKG data environment, reducing complexity for users and encouraging use of the richer, full GKG dataset.

**Summary:**

- Adding unique record identifiers to the GKG improved the ability to uniquely reference and manage individual records, enhancing integration with the Event Database and overall data usability.

- The counts-only file was removed because most users require the full contextual data, making the smaller counts-only file redundant and simplifying the data environment by maintaining only the full GKG file.

The Leetaru (2012) algorithm facilitates the extraction of both location and organization names from text through specialized named entity recognition processes designed to identify and disambiguate these entities with geographic and organizational specificity.

### Extraction of Location Names:
- The algorithm aggressively extracts every possible locative referent from the text, which may result in a slightly elevated level of false positives.
- Locations are identified and represented with multiple fields including:
  - **Location Type:** Specifies the geographic resolution (e.g., country, US state, US city, world city, world state).
  - **Location FullName:** The exact name as expressed in the text, capturing alternative spellings and transliterations (e.g., Mecca vs. Makkah).
  - **Location FeatureID:** A unique identifier from the GNS or GNIS databases that resolves different spellings or names to the same geographic feature.
  - **Location CountryCode, ADM1Code, ADM2Code:** Codes that provide hierarchical administrative information about the location.
  - **Latitude and Longitude:** Centroid coordinates for mapping the location.
- The algorithm uses these identifiers and codes to disambiguate locations and to allow filtering by geographic specificity.
- For accurate identification, the **FeatureID** is preferred over the textual name to collapse or unify references to the same location despite spelling variations.
- The algorithm also provides enhanced location fields (V2ENHANCEDLOCATIONS) that include character offsets of location mentions in the text and multiple mentions of the same location.

### Extraction of Organization Names:
- The algorithm extracts all company and organization names found in the text, including corporations, intergovernmental organizations (IGOs), non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and local organizations.
- These are listed in a semicolon-delimited format similar to the person names extraction.
- The extraction is based on the same Leetaru (2012) algorithm, which is designed to handle diverse naming conventions and entity types.

### Specific Considerations for Accurate Identification:
- **Aggressiveness in Location Extraction:** The algorithm runs in a more aggressive stance to capture all possible locative references, which can increase false positives, so users should be aware of this trade-off.
- **Disambiguation Using FeatureIDs:** Because locations can have multiple accepted formal or informal names and alternative spellings, the algorithm relies on unique GNS/GNIS FeatureIDs to unify these variants.
- **Hierarchical Administrative Codes:** Use of ADM1 and ADM2 codes helps in precisely locating administrative divisions and districts, which is important for detailed geographic resolution.
- **Character Offsets:** Enhanced fields include character offsets to link entity mentions to their exact positions in the text, facilitating contextual analysis and cross-referencing with other extracted entities.
- **Handling of Different Geographic Resolutions:** The algorithm distinguishes between country-level, state-level, and city-level matches, providing centroid coordinates accordingly.
- **Specialized Person Name Recognition:** Although not directly about locations or organizations, the algorithm also includes a unique name recognition component designed to improve accuracy for African, Asian, and Middle Eastern names, indicating a broader attention to diverse naming conventions that likely extends to organizations and locations.

In summary, the Leetaru (2012) algorithm extracts location and organization names by combining aggressive entity recognition with detailed geographic coding and unique feature identifiers to accurately identify and disambiguate entities, while providing metadata such as character offsets and hierarchical administrative codes to support precise mapping and analysis.

and one containing the full GKG file.  The original rationale for having two separate files was that

all applications use the full GKG file in order to make use of its thematic and other data fields to 
contextualize those counts and to tie them into the GDELT Event Database.  Thus, we are 
eliminating the separate counts-only file to simplify the GKG data environment.

production status.  This means that the file format is now stabilized and will not change.

released in that format.  With the debut of the GKG 2.1 format in February 2015, the format has 
remained largely the same, but with the addition of several new fields to accommodate a number of 
significant enhancements to the GKG system.  While it was originally intended to release these new 
features in the GKG 2.0 format through the V2EXTRASXML field, the integral nature of several of these

accommodate these goals.  Users will find that code designed for the GKG 2.0 format can be adapted to

special subcollection datasets and never made an appearance for the daily news content, a GKG 2.0 
compatibility feed will not be made available and only the GKG 1.0 and GKG 2.1 formats will be 
supported for news content.

revolve around how entries are clustered and the minimum criteria for an article to be included in the 
GKG stream.  Under the GKG 1.0 format, a deduplication process similar to that used for the Event 
stream was applied to the daily GKG export, grouping together all articles yielding the same GKG 
metadata.  Thus, two articles listing the same set of locations, themes, people, and organizations would

to appear in the GKG.  Under GKG 1.0 and 2.0, an article was required to have at least one successfully

many topics monitored by GDELT, such as cybersecurity, constitutional discourse, and major policy

To sum up the GKG in a single sentence, it connects every person, organization, location, count, theme, 
news source, and event across the planet into a single massive network that captures what’s happening 
around the world, what its context is and who’s involved, and how the world is feeling about it, every 
single day.

on November 3, 2013 and in those fourteen months the GKG system has found application in an 
incredible number and diversity of fields.  The uniqueness of the GKG indicators in capturing the latent 
dimensions of society that precede physical unrest and their global scope has enabled truly

capabilities of greatest interest to the GKG community, and with this Version 2.1 release of the GKG, we

alpha status) in recognition of the widespread production use of the system today.

The enhancements in GKG data, such as the realtime measurement of over 2,300 emotions and themes through the GCAM (Global Content Analysis Measures) module, are directly related to the evolution of the GKG file format from version 2.0 to 2.1. These enhancements necessitated changes in the file format and article inclusion criteria to support the richer, more granular data.

**Relation of GCAM Enhancements to GKG File Format Evolution (2.0 to 2.1):**

- **New Fields Added:**  
  GKG 2.1 introduced several new fields to accommodate significant enhancements like GCAM's realtime emotional and thematic measurements. While initially planned to be included in the V2EXTRASXML field in GKG 2.0, the integral nature of these fields and the need for better alignment with the Events dataset format required a formal upgrade to GKG 2.1. This upgrade allowed structural mapping and hierarchical representation of these new data dimensions.

- **Document-Level Metadata:**  
  The GCAM system assesses emotions and themes at the individual article level, which required the GKG 2.1 format to stop clustering multiple articles with identical metadata into a single record (as was done in GKG 1.0 and 2.0). Instead, GKG 2.1 records each article separately, preserving unique GCAM scores and metadata per document. This change supports the detailed emotional and thematic analysis enabled by GCAM.

- **Unique Record Identifiers:**  
  To manage the increased granularity and to uniquely identify each article's metadata (including GCAM scores), GKG 2.1 assigns a globally unique identifier (GKGRECORDID) to each record.

**Changes in Article Inclusion Criteria Supporting These Enhancements:**

- **Relaxed Geographic Location Requirement:**  
  Previously (in GKG 1.0 and 2.0), an article had to contain at least one successfully identified and geocoded geographic location to be included in the GKG. This excluded many relevant articles on topics without strong geographic references (e.g., cybersecurity, constitutional discourse).

- **Inclusion Based on Any Extracted Information:**  
  Starting with GKG 2.1, an article is included if it contains *any* successfully extracted information, including GCAM emotional and thematic scores. This means articles without geographic mentions but with emotional or thematic metadata are now included, broadening the scope and relevance of the GKG data.

- **No Clustering of Articles:**  
  Because GCAM scores can vary significantly even among articles sharing the same locations, themes, people, and organizations, GKG 2.1 treats each article as a separate entry rather than clustering them. This preserves the unique emotional and thematic context of each article.

**Summary:**

- The realtime measurement of 2,300+ emotions and themes by GCAM required GKG to evolve from 2.0 to 2.1 to structurally support these new data fields and to align better with event data formats.
- GKG 2.1 stopped clustering articles with identical metadata to preserve unique emotional/thematic scores per article.
- The article inclusion criteria were broadened in GKG 2.1 to include articles without geographic locations but with any extracted metadata, including GCAM scores, enabling richer and more comprehensive data coverage.

These changes collectively enable the GKG to provide a more nuanced, detailed, and comprehensive representation of global news content, including emotional and thematic undercurrents at a planetary scale.

global media system.  Each mention of an event receives its own entry in the Mentions table – thus an

events being recontextualized into present actions.  If a news report mentions multiple events, each

on its English translation.

media spanning the entire globe, one finds that journalism is rife with ambiguities, assumed background

President Barack Obama met with Russian President Vladimir Putin yesterday at a trade summit in Paris, 
France.”  Instead, an event mention might more commonly appear as “Obama and Putin were in Paris

Ukraine.”  To which of the two leader(s) do “he” and “his” refer?  Is Obama discussing Obama’s policy on

Event sourcing with the **DATEADDED** field helps event tracking in the Mentions table by providing a precise timestamp (in YYYYMMDDHHMMSS UTC format) of when the event was first added to the master database. This timestamp allows users to:

- Identify the original occurrence time of the event at a 15-minute resolution.
- Distinguish between multiple mentions of the same event across different news reports over time.
- Track the trajectory and evolution of an event as it is mentioned repeatedly in various articles, including mentions long after the original event date (e.g., anniversary or historical references).
- Filter mentions by the event's original date to analyze mentions of events of a particular vintage or to identify first mentions versus subsequent mentions.

Since the Mentions table records each mention of an event separately, even if the same event is mentioned many times, the **EventTimeDate** field (which corresponds to the original event's DATEADDED) allows linking all these mentions back to the same event source. This enables comprehensive tracking of how an event is discussed and evolves in media over time.

---

The **Confidence** field in the Mentions table is crucial for event sourcing and event tracking because:

- It quantifies GDELT’s confidence in the accuracy of the event extraction from each individual article, expressed as a percentage from 10% to 100%.
- Higher confidence scores indicate mentions where the event extraction was less ambiguous and required fewer aggressive natural language processing interventions (like coreference resolution or grammatical restructuring).
- Sorting mentions by confidence allows users to prioritize or filter for the most reliable and unambiguous mentions of an event, improving the quality of event tracking.
- Since news reports often contain ambiguous language, pronouns, or complex references, the confidence score helps manage the uncertainty inherent in automated event extraction.
- This is especially important when the same event is mentioned multiple times with varying clarity; confidence scores help identify which mentions are most trustworthy for analysis.

Together, the **DATEADDED** field (event sourcing) and the **Confidence** field (extraction reliability) enable robust tracking of events through multiple mentions in the media, allowing analysts to trace the spread, evolution, and reliability of information about an event over time.

Abstract
In this work we study various Retrieval Augmented Regeneration (RAG) approaches to gain an
understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of each approach in a question-answering analysis. To
gain this understanding we use a case-study subset of the Global Database of Events, Language, and
Tone (GDELT) dataset as well as a corpus of raw text scraped from the online news articles. To retrieve
information from the text corpus we implement a traditional vector store RAG as well as state-of-the-art
large language model (LLM) based approaches for automatically constructing KGs and retrieving the
relevant subgraphs. In addition to these corpus approaches, we develop a novel ontology-based framework
for constructing knowledge graphs (KGs) from GDELT directly which leverages the underlying schema
of GDELT to create structured representations of global events. For retrieving relevant information from
the ontology-based KGs we implement both direct graph queries and state-of-the-art graph retrieval
approaches. We compare the performance of each method in a question-answering task. We find that
while our ontology-based KGs are valuable for question-answering, automated extraction of the relevant
subgraphs is challenging. Conversely, LLM-generated KGs, while capturing event summaries, often lack
consistency and interpretability. Our findings suggest benefits of a synergistic approach between ontology
and LLM-based KG construction, with proposed avenues toward that end.

In this work we study several approaches for communicating with a corpus of text via relevant text and
knowledge graph (KG) representation and retrieval facilitated by Large Language Models (LLMs). Our
goal is to understand the benefits and drawbacks of Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) approaches to
corpus management and anlysis when combined with an LLM. Throughout we use as a case study a novel

shown that reasoning over the typical RAG framework, which only takes advantage of the unstructured text

base [5, 7, 15, 31]. More specifically, KGs [8] are graph structures which are richly attributed with typing
and semantic information on both nodes and edges. KG techniques provide ways to automatically query
and extract information stored in a KG without the user explicitly needing to understand query languages
to probe their knowledge base. Typically, these AI-based search algorithms find subgraphs that can be used
to answer a user-provided query.

extraction (see different research directions outlined by Pan et al. [18]). In particular, reflective of KGs
being used to enhance LLM outputs, LLMs can be used to enhance existing KGs or create new ones entirely

format.  The   Records are stored one per line, separated by a newline (\n) and are tab-delimited (note

changes as noted below.  In addition to the Event table there is now a new Mentions table that records 
all mentions of each event.  As an event is mentioned across multiple news reports, each of those

identify the “best” news report to return for a given event (filtering all mentions of an event for those

  - Clustering based on shared metadata was discontinued.  
  - Each article is represented as a separate entry, even if multiple articles share the same locations, themes, people, and organizations.  
  - This change was driven by the introduction of the GCAM system, which assesses over 2,300 emotions and themes per article, meaning articles with the same metadata could have very different emotional/thematic scores.  
  - Additionally, real-time translation required the ability to track metadata provenance at the document level, which clustering would obscure.

  - An article had to contain at least one successfully identified and geocoded geographic location to be included in the GKG output.

  - The geographic location requirement was removed.

  - Allows users to analyze each article individually rather than aggregated clusters, enhancing analytical precision.

  - Increases the comprehensiveness and relevance of the GKG dataset for diverse user communities and research areas.  
  - Prevents exclusion of important thematic and emotional content that would otherwise be missed under the geographic location requirement.

actually representing all of the latent dimensions, geography, and network structure of the global news.  
It applies an array of highly sophisticated natural language processing algorithms to each document to 
compute a range of codified metadata encoding key latent and contextual dimensions of the document.  
To sum up the GKG in a single sentence, it connects every person, organization, location, count, theme, 
news source, and event across the planet into a single massive network that captures what’s happening 
around the world, what its context is and who’s involved, and how the world is feeling about it, every 
single day. 
 
It has been just short of sixteen months since the original prototype introduction of the GKG 1.0 system 
on November 3, 2013 and in those fourteen months the GKG system has found application in an 
incredible number and diversity of fields.  The uniqueness of the GKG indicators in capturing the latent 
dimensions of society that precede physical unrest and their global scope has enabled truly 
unimaginable new applications.  We’ve learned a lot over the past year in terms of the features and

alpha status) in recognition of the widespread production use of the system today.

The GDELT Global Knowledge Graph (GKG) Version 2.1 improves role and location association and introduces several new features as follows:

### Improvements in Role and Location Association:
- **Character Offset for References:**  
  GKG 2.1 provides the approximate character offset of each reference to an object (such as a person, organization, location, or role) within the original article text. This allows for simple proximity-based contextualization, enabling users to associate specific people with their corresponding locations and functional roles more accurately.  
  - For example, if an article mentions Barack Obama, John Kerry, Vladimir Putin, the United States, Russia, and roles like President and Secretary of State, the character offset data helps determine which person is mentioned closer to which location or role. This proximity information helps recover functional, thematic, and geographic affiliations that were difficult to establish in previous versions.

### New Features Introduced in GKG 2.1:
1. **Over 100 New Themes:**  
   The GKG now includes more than 100 new themes covering a wide range of topics such as economic indicators (e.g., price gouging, price of heating oil), infrastructure (e.g., construction of power generation capacity), social issues (e.g., marginalization, burning in effigy), expanded lists of infectious diseases, ethnic groups, terrorism organizations, over 600 global humanitarian and development aid organizations, global currencies, and new taxonomies for animals and plants to track species migration and poaching.

2. **Extensible XML Block (V2EXTRASXML):**  
   A new XML-formatted field allows encoding of specialized data types that apply only to subsets of the collection, such as citation lists in academic literature. This extensibility supports encoding highly specialized enhanced information from diverse input streams beyond mainstream news.

3. **Unique Record Identifiers:**  
   Each GKG record is now assigned a unique identifier, facilitating easier referencing and management of individual records across the entire dataset.

4. **Single Data File Format:**  
   The previous separation of GKG data into two files (one for counts only and one full file) has been eliminated. Now, all data is provided in a single comprehensive file, simplifying data handling and ensuring users have access to all thematic and contextual data.

5. **Production Status and Stability:**  
   GKG 2.1 has moved from alpha experimental status to production status, meaning the file format is now stable and will not change, supporting widespread production use.

6. **Changes in Document Clustering and Inclusion Criteria:**  
   - GKG 2.1 no longer clusters multiple articles with the same metadata into a single record; instead, each article appears as a separate entry.  
   - The minimum inclusion criteria for articles have been relaxed: articles without any geocoded location but containing any extracted information (including emotional scores) are now included, broadening the scope of the dataset to cover topics without strong geographic references (e.g., cybersecurity, constitutional discourse).

---

### Summary:
GKG 2.1 enhances the ability to associate roles and locations by providing character offsets for references within articles, enabling proximity-based contextualization. It also introduces over 100 new thematic categories, an extensible XML field for specialized data, unique record identifiers, a unified data file format, and improved inclusion criteria, all while stabilizing the format for production use.

EVENT GEOGRAPHY 
 
The final set of fields add a novel enhancement to the CAMEO taxonomy, georeferencing each event 
along three primary dimensions to the landmark-centroid level.  To do this, the fulltext of the source 
document is processed using fulltext geocoding and automatic disambiguation to identify every 
geographic reference.3  The closest reference to each of the two actors and to the action reference are 
then encoded in these fields.  The georeferenced location for an actor may not always match the 
Actor1_CountryCode or Actor2_CountryCode field, such as in a case where the President of Russia is 
visiting Washington, DC in the United States, in which case the Actor1_CountryCode would contain the 
code for Russia, while the georeferencing fields below would contain a match for Washington, DC.  It 
may not always be possible for the system to locate a match for each actor or location, in which case 
one or more of the fields may be blank.  The Action fields capture the location information closest to the 
point in the event description that contains the actual statement of action and is the best location to use 
for placing events on a map or in other spatial context.   
 
To find all events located in or relating to a specific city or geographic landmark, the Geo_FeatureID 
column should be used, rather than the Geo_Fullname column.  This is because the Geo_Fullname 
column captures the name of the location as expressed in the text and thus reflects differences in 
transliteration, alternative spellings, and alternative names for the same location.  For example, Mecca 
is often spelled Makkah, while Jeddah is commonly spelled Jiddah or Jaddah.  The Geo_Fullname column 
will reflect each of these different spellings, while the Geo_FeatureID column will resolve them all to the 
same unique GNS or GNIS feature identification number.  For more information on the GNS and GNIS 
identifiers, see Leetaru (2012). 4 
 
When looking for events in or relating to a specific country, such as Syria, there are two possible filtering 
methods.  The first is to use the Actor_CountryCode fields in the Actor section to look for all actors 
having the SYR (Syria) code.  However, conflict zones are often accompanied by high degrees of 
uncertainty in media reporting and a news article might mention only “Unidentified gunmen stormed a 
house and shot 12 civilians.”  In this case, the Actor_CountryCode fields for Actor1 and Actor2 would 
both be blank, since the article did not specify the actor country affiliations, while their 
Geo_CountryCode values (and the ActorGeo_CountryCode for the event) would specify Syria.  This can 
result in dramatic differences when examining active conflict zones.  The second method is to examine 
the ActorGeo_CountryCode for the location of the event.  This will also capture situations such as the 
United States criticizing a statement by Russia regarding a specific Syrian attack.

NumArts used to indicate the multiple entries, while in the 2.1 format each document has a separate 
entry in the file.  Fields prefaced with “V1” indicate they are identical in format and population to the 
previous GKG format.  Those prefaced with “V1.5” mean they are largely similar, but have some

record, the GKG system uses a date-oriented serial number.  Each GKG record ID takes the form 
“YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-X” or “YYYYMMDDHHMMSS-TX” in which the first portion of the ID is the 
full date+time of the 15 minute update batch that this record was created in, followed by a 
dash, followed by sequential numbering for all GKG records created as part of that update 
batch.  Records originating from a document that was translated by GDELT Translingual will have 
a capital “T” appearing immediately after the dash to allow filtering of English/non-English 
material simply by its record identifier.  Thus, the fifth GKG record created as part of the update 
batch generated at 3:30AM on February 3, 2015 would have a GKGRECORDID of 
“20150203033000-5” and if it was based on a French-language document that was translated, it 
would have the ID “20150203033000-T5”.  This ID can be used to uniquely identify this 
particular record across the entire GKG database.  Note that due to the presence of the dash, 
this field should be treated as a string field and NOT as a numeric field.

adds a series of new capabilities that greatly enhance what can be done with the GKG data, opening entirely new analytic opportunities. Some of the most significant changes:  Realtime Measurement of 2,300 Emotions and Themes. The GDELT Global Content Analysis Measures (GCAM) module represents what we believe is the largest deployment of sentiment analysis in the world: bringing together 24 emotional measurement packages that together assess more than 2,300 emotions and themes from every article in realtime, multilingual dimensions natively assessing the emotions of 15 languages (Arabic, Basque, Catalan, Chinese, French, Galician, German, Hindi, Indonesian, Korean, Pashto, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, and Urdu). GCAM is designed to enable unparalleled assessment of the emotional undercurrents and reaction at a planetary scale by bringing together an incredible array of dimensions, from LIWC’s “Anxiety” to Lexicoder’s “Positivity” to WordNet Affect’s “Smugness” to RID’s “Passivity”.  Realtime Translation of 65 Languages. GDELT 2.0 brings with it the public debut of GDELT Translingual, representing what we believe is the largest realtime streaming news machine translation deployment in the world: all global news that GDELT monitors in 65 languages, representing 98.4% of its daily non-English monitoring volume, is translated in realtime into English for processing through the entire GDELT Event and GKG/GCAM pipelines. GDELT Translingual is designed to allow GDELT to monitor the entire planet at full volume, creating the very first glimpses of a world without language barriers. The GKG system now processes every news report monitored by GDELT across these 65 languages, making it possible to trace people, organizations, locations, themes, and emotions across languages and media systems.  Relevant Imagery, Videos, and Social Embeds. A large fraction of the world’s news outlets now specify a hand-selected image for each article to appear when it is shared via social media that represents the core focus of the article. GDELT identifies this imagery in a wide array of formats including Open Graph, Twitter Cards, Google+, IMAGE_SRC, and SailThru formats. In addition, GDELT also uses a set of highly specialized algorithms to analyze the article content itself to identify inline imagery of high likely relevance to the story, along with videos and embedded social media posts (such as embedded Tweets or YouTube or Vine videos), a list of which is compiled. This makes it possible to gain a unique ground-level view into emerging situations anywhere in the world, even in those areas with very little social media penetration, and to act as a kind of curated list of social posts in those areas with strong social use.  Quotes, Names, and Amounts. The world’s news contains a wealth of information on food prices, aid promises, numbers of troops, tanks, and protesters, and nearly any other countable item. GDELT 2.0 now attempts to compile a list of all “amounts” expressed in each article to offer numeric context to global events. In parallel, a new Names engine augments the existing Person and Organization names engines by identifying an array of other kinds of proper names, such as named events (Orange Revolution / Umbrella Movement), occurrences like the World Cup, named dates like Holocaust Remembrance Day, on through named legislation like Iran Nuclear Weapon Free Act, Affordable Care Act and Rouge National Urban Park Initiative. Finally, GDELT also identifies attributable quotes from each article, making it possible to see the evolving language used by political leadership across the world. '

response:
The real-time measurement of 2,300 emotions and themes by the GCAM (Global Content Analysis Measures) system significantly influenced changes in the GKG 2.1 format and its article inclusion criteria in the following ways:

1. **Elimination of Clustering of Articles with Identical Metadata:**
   - In the earlier GKG 1.0 format, articles with the same metadata (locations, themes, people, organizations) were clustered together into a single row, with a count of the number of articles (NumArticles).
   - With GCAM assessing over 2,300 emotions and themes for each article, it became clear that articles with identical metadata could have very different emotional and thematic profiles.
   - Therefore, GKG 2.1 no longer clusters articles based on shared metadata. Instead, each article appears as a separate entry in the GKG stream, even if multiple articles share the same locations, themes, people, and organizations. This allows the distinct GCAM emotional scores to be preserved and analyzed at the individual article level.

2. **Change in Article Inclusion Criteria:**
   - Previously (GKG 1.0 and 2.0), an article had to contain at least one successfully identified and geocoded geographic location to be included in the GKG.
   - Many important topics (e.g., cybersecurity, constitutional discourse, policy discussions) often lack geographic mentions and were thus excluded.
   - With the introduction of GCAM emotional and thematic scoring, GKG 2.1 expanded the inclusion criteria: an article is included if it contains **any** successfully extracted information, including GCAM emotional scores.
   - This means articles without geographic mentions but with emotional or thematic data from GCAM are now included, broadening the scope and relevance of the GKG dataset.

3. **Structural and Format Adjustments:**
   - The addition of GCAM data required new fields in the GKG 2.1 format to accommodate these extensive emotional and thematic measures.
   - The format was upgraded from 2.0 to 2.1 to better align with the Events dataset format and to enable future hierarchical representations.
   - The NUMARTS field used for counting clustered articles was discontinued because each article is now a separate record.

4. **Provenance and Translation Tracking:**
   - Because GCAM processes articles in real-time and across multiple languages (with real-time translation of 65 languages), GKG 2.1 includes fields like MentionDocTranslationInfo to track the provenance and translation details of each document, ensuring accurate interpretation of emotional scores.

**Summary:**  
The GCAM system’s real-time measurement of 2,300 emotions and themes necessitated that GKG 2.1 treat each article as a unique record rather than clustering by shared metadata, and broadened the inclusion criteria to accept articles without geographic data but with emotional/thematic content. This enhanced the granularity, scope, and analytic potential of the GKG dataset.
